terms.definition: An iterative, interrogative technique used to explore the cause-and-effect relationships underlying a particular problem by repeatedly asking the question 'Why?'.
A controlled experiment that compares two versions (A and B) of a single variable to determine which performs better against a key metric.
A form of logical inference that starts with an observation and seeks to find the simplest and most likely explanation. It is often described as an 'inference to the best explanation'.
The obligation to accept responsibility for one's actions and their outcomes.

A structured de-briefing process for analyzing a completed event or project. It focuses on four key questions: What was supposed to happen? What actually happened? Why was there a difference? What will we do next time?
A position of agreement or alliance.
A cognitive process of transferring information or meaning from a source subject to a target subject.
The detailed examination of the elements or structure of something.
An observation that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
The original term for Tool 6, representing the act of putting a plan into practice.
The act of collecting, organizing, and preserving records for long-term storage and future reference.
A visual representation of the structure of an argument, mapping claims, evidence, and warrants.
The expression of approval or agreement.
The evaluation of the nature, quality, or ability of someone or something.
Evidence or proof of something; a formal declaration that something is true.
The original term for Tool 1, representing the process of becoming aware of and responsive to a problem or phenomenon in its full context.
A research method that uses personal experience ('auto') to describe and interpret cultural beliefs and practices ('ethno').
Knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.
A condition in which different elements are in the correct proportions.
A detailed plan or technical drawing that provides a complete set of instructions for building or executing something.
An ideation technique where designers physically act out a scenario to generate insights from embodied experience.
A group creativity technique for generating a large number of ideas by encouraging spontaneous contributions.
The process of constructing something from parts.
The action of checking or adjusting a measuring instrument or one's judgment.
A problem-solving paradigm that involves using the solutions to past, similar problems (cases) to inform the solution to a new problem.

A domain in the Cynefin framework characterized by the absence of knowable cause-and-effect relationships. The context is a crisis. The correct approach is to Act -> Sense -> Respond to create stability.
An act of selecting or making a decision when faced with two or more possibilities.

A domain in the Cynefin framework (formerly 'Simple') where cause-and-effect relationships are obvious to everyone. The context is stable and known. The correct approach is to Sense -> Categorize -> Respond by applying best practices.
The careful, sustained, and critical interpretation of a brief passage of a text.
A creative process where multiple stakeholders, often including end-users, collaborate to produce a mutually valued outcome.
The process of arranging rules or ideas into a systematic code.
An external tool, template, or process that provides temporary support for a learner, reducing cognitive load and allowing them to perform a task that would otherwise be too complex.
The quality of being logical, consistent, and forming a unified whole.
The act of dedicating oneself to a particular course of action.

A domain in the Cynefin framework where cause and effect can only be understood in retrospect. The system is unpredictable and emergent. This is the domain of 'unknown unknowns.' The correct approach is to Probe -> Sense -> Respond.

A domain in the Cynefin framework where there is a clear relationship between cause and effect, but it is not obvious and requires expert analysis to discover. This is the domain of 'known unknowns.' The correct approach is to Sense -> Analyze -> Respond.
The forming or devising of a plan or idea.
The action or manner of managing an activity.
To bring together so that a link is established.
A period of rest or inactivity following a period of intense work, allowing for subconscious processing and memory consolidation.
The explicit limitations (time, budget, ethics, medium) that define the boundaries for a project.
The action of formally discussing or seeking advice.
Deep reflective thought.
The circumstances that form the setting for an event or idea.
The practice of situating a subject within its historical, cultural, and political context.
The part played in bringing about a result or helping something to advance.
The process of coming together to meet at a point.
A change that rectifies an error or inaccuracy.
A systematic process for calculating and comparing the benefits and costs of a decision.
To bring something into existence.
A document used to guide the development of creative work by defining its goals, audience, and constraints.
The technique of exposing oneself to specific stimuli (e.g., images, words, ideas) to activate related concepts in memory, making them more available for use in a subsequent creative task.
The use of imagination or original ideas to create something.
A detailed analysis and assessment of a work.
The process of trying to acquire or develop a quality or skill.

A conceptual framework used to aid decision-making by categorizing contexts into five domains: Clear, Complicated, Complex, Chaotic, and Disorder. Each domain has a different relationship between cause and effect, requiring a different approach to action.
The process of identifying and removing errors from computer hardware or software.
The original term for Tool 4, representing a conclusion or resolution reached after consideration.
A formal record of key decisions made during a project, including the options considered, the criteria used, the final choice, and the rationale.
The process of formally taking a system or facility out of service.
An action that is performed intentionally or consciously.
A formal academic ritual where a candidate defends their thesis or dissertation against challenges from a committee of experts.
In Agile development, a formal, shared checklist of criteria that a product increment must meet to be considered complete.
A highly structured form of practice aimed at improving performance. It involves breaking down a skill, focusing on specific weaknesses, and using immediate feedback for correction.
Long and careful consideration or discussion.
A collection of reusable components and clear standards that can be assembled to build applications.
The identification of the nature of a problem by examination of the symptoms.
The practice of training oneself to obey rules or a code of behavior.
A measure of a scholarly work's impact based on how it is cited, debated, and integrated into the ongoing conversation of a field.

The central domain of the Cynefin framework (also called 'Confused'), representing a state where one does not know which of the other domains (Clear, Complicated, Complex, Chaotic) applies. The only way out is to break the situation down and diagnose the context.
The process of moving in different directions from a common point.
A process where, in addition to correcting an error, one also questions and modifies the underlying assumptions that led to the error.
The core act of application in writing, translating an outline into continuous prose.
A core Daoist concept of spontaneous, natural action that aligns with the flow of a system.
A tangible or visible form of an idea, quality, or feeling.
The process of complex patterns arising out of a multiplicity of relatively simple interactions.
The process of acting something out.
A single, critical user story that is built first to validate that all architectural components of a system are connected correctly.
A shared belief that a team is safe for interpersonal risk-taking.
Finding a new, often surprising, use for an existing tool, technology, or idea.
The carrying out of a plan or course of action.
The act of providing a typical example of something.
A public display of works of art or items of interest.
A scientific procedure undertaken to test a hypothesis.

A psychological technique designed to help people confront their fears. When you're afraid of something, you might avoid it. But avoidance prevents you from learning that the thing you fear may not be as dangerous as you think.
The process of making known one's thoughts or feelings.
The process of making or manufacturing something from raw materials.
The skill of guiding a group process to make it easier and more productive.

One of the two core personas in the framework, representing the guide, coach, or leader responsible for managing the process and creating the conditions for the team to succeed. The Facilitator view focuses on "How do I help my team make progress right now?"
The principle that a statement is scientific only if it can be proven false.
Information about reactions to a product or performance. Differentiates between Verification (Technical feedback) and Validation (User/Value feedback).
Research conducted in a natural, real-world environment.
An optimal psychological state of being fully immersed and energized in an activity.
A visual diagram that represents a workflow or process.
The center of interest or activity.
The practice of performing an action with full, non-judgmental attention to the process and the present moment.
The process of making something formal or official.
The action of creating or preparing something methodically.
The conscious act of choosing how to describe a situation, which in turn determines the range of possible solutions.
The achievement of something desired, promised, or predicted.
The cognitive process of abstracting a general rule from specific examples.
The original term for Tool 3, representing the process of producing or creating possibilities.
The quality of being kind and generous.
A formal decision point to either continue with a project or terminate it.
Defines the facilitator's role in Tool 6 as a 'guide on the side' who observes performance and provides targeted, minimal interventions.
Defines the facilitator's role in Tool 3 as the manager of the creative process.

A compelling, open-ended question that provides the central focus and purpose for an entire inquiry. A good guiding question is specific enough to be actionable but open enough to allow for discovery.
The quality of forming a pleasing and consistent whole.
Mental shortcuts or rules of thumb that simplify complex problem-solving.

In JTBD theory, this refers to the specific context in which a user decides to "hire" a product or service to solve a problem. It encompasses the user's situation, their emotional state, and the "push" and "pull" forces acting upon them.
A linguistic formula for framing brainstorming prompts to be optimistic and open-ended.
A proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.
The formation of ideas or concepts.
The process of putting a decision or plan into effect.
The establishment or starting point of an institution or activity.
The process of stepping away from a problem to allow for unconscious processing.
An act of asking for information; a process of investigation.
A basic structure underlying a system, concept, or text.
A deep understanding of a person or thing.
The process of being mentally stimulated to do or feel something creative.
A direction or order.

The ability to use integrated knowledge and experience to make sound, context-aware judgments. In the framework, this represents the highest form of synthesis, where principles are integrated to guide future ethical and effective action.
The action of combining one thing with another so that they become a whole.
The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles; the state of being whole and undivided.

The conscious experience of non-conscious pattern-matching. The framework treats these 'gut feelings' as valid data points for further inquiry, often grounded in interoceptive signals or extensive past experience.
The action of inventing something that has not previously existed.
A complete list of items.
A pedagogical approach that frames the facilitator's role as a designer of compelling 'invitations' to learn.
The repetition of a process.
A brief, powerful statement that describes a user's situation, motivation, and desired outcome. It follows the format: "When [situation], I want to [motivation], so I can [expected outcome]."
An innovation framework that focuses on the underlying 'job' a customer is trying to accomplish.
The ability to make considered decisions or come to sensible conclusions.
An assessment process where a panel of experts (a 'jury') evaluates work against disciplinary standards.
A Japanese philosophy of continuous, incremental improvement.
The ability to apply knowledge or skills learned in one context to a new, novel context.
The act of releasing a product to the market.
To gain or acquire knowledge of or skill in something by study, experience, or being taught.
In systems thinking, places within a complex system where a small shift can produce large changes.
To give one's attention to a sound or to take notice of and act on what someone says.
A scholarly paper that presents the current knowledge on a topic.
Reasoning conducted or assessed according to strict principles of validity.
A flaw in the structure of a deductive argument which renders the argument invalid. Common examples include confirmation bias, straw man arguments, and confusing correlation with causation.
A diagrammatic representation of an area or structure.
Comprehensive knowledge or skill in a subject or accomplishment.
The process of reaching a state of full development.
The original term for Tool 10, representing awareness and understanding of one's own thought processes.
The pedagogical act of demonstrating a skill or thought process for a learner.
A visual collage of images, text, and samples used to define a project's aesthetic and emotional territory.
The novel inquiries that are made possible by the completion of a research project.
A practice of receiving communication with full, non-judgmental attention.
The action of observing something carefully to gain information.
A form of communication wherein knowledge and cultural material is transmitted orally.
The arrangement of things in relation to each other according to a particular sequence, pattern, or method.
The original term for Tool 2, representing the action of finding one's position relative to unfamiliar surroundings.
The way a thing turns out; a consequence.
Something left or handed down by a predecessor.
A plan giving the essential features of something but not the detail.
The original term for Tool 10, representing the planning and coordination of the elements of a situation to produce a desired effect.
A method of describing good design practices as a network of solutions to common problems.
The process of identifying and understanding recurring patterns.
The evaluation of work by people with similar competencies.
A fact or situation that is observed to exist, especially one whose cause is in question.
Engaging in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than a serious or practical purpose.
A set of rules or suggestions suitable for a particular activity.
A solemn promise or undertaking.
A thing that may happen or be the case.
The actual application or use of an idea, belief, or method.

One of the two core personas in the framework, representing the individual or team directly engaged in the work of inquiry and creation. The Practitioner view focuses on "What do I need to do right now to make progress?"
The action of deciding the relative importance of a set of items.

The correct method for acting in the Complex domain of the Cynefin framework. It involves conducting a small, safe-to-fail experiment (Probe), observing what patterns emerge (Sense), and then adapting your next action based on that feedback (Respond).
A concise description of an issue to be addressed.
A type of long-term memory involving how to perform different actions and skills. It is the 'muscle memory' that allows us to perform tasks automatically, without conscious thought.
The proactive task of identifying, analyzing and improving upon existing business processes.
The degree to which a product satisfies strong market demand.
Evidence or argument establishing a fact or the truth of a statement.
The technique of imagining a future event has already occurred to improve foresight.
The cognitive ability to remember to perform a planned action or recall a planned intention at some future point in time (e.g., remembering to stop at the store on the way home).
A psychological phenomenon where teaching, pretending to teach, or preparing to teach information to others helps a person learn that information more effectively.
A detailed, step-by-step set of instructions that ensures a process is repeatable and consistent.
The act of building a preliminary version of an idea. Distinguishes between Low-Fidelity (Tool 3) and High-Fidelity (Tool 6) based on the NASA TRL scale.
A deliberate pedagogical act designed to create cognitive dissonance and spark curiosity.
The difficult but necessary act of removing a part of the work that is clever or beautiful but does not serve the whole.
The act of making a work publicly available through a formal channel.
To remove an unwanted feeling, memory, or condition.
The reason for which something is done or created.

The opposing forces that influence a user's decision in JTBD theory. The 'Push' is the pain of the current situation driving them to seek a change. The 'Pull' is the appeal of the new solution's promise.
The systematic process of checking whether a product meets specified requirements.
A responsibility assignment chart (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed).
The practice of exchanging things for mutual benefit.
The action of identifying something from having encountered it before.
The original term for Tool 7, representing the process of improving something by making small changes.
Serious thought or consideration.
The capacity to reflect on one's actions so as to engage in a process of continuous learning.
A trial performance of a work for later public performance.
The action of independently repeating an experiment to verify the results.
The systematic investigation into sources to establish facts and reach new conclusions.
The action of solving a problem or contentious matter.
To settle or find a solution to a problem or contentious matter.
The duty to deal with something.
A formal Agile ceremony for a team to reflect on its process.
The action of revising a text.
A prioritization framework used to evaluate ideas based on four factors: Reach, Impact, Confidence, and Effort.
The humanistic practice of generating multiple, competing interpretations of a text.
A high-level strategic plan that connects short-term work to a long-term vision.
A method of problem solving used for identifying the root causes of faults or problems.
The quality of being particularly noticeable or important.
A temporary structure of support. In pedagogy (Vygotsky), it refers to instructional techniques (soft or hard) that provide temporary support to a learner to reach the Zone of Proximal Development.
To increase in size, number, or importance.
A brainstorming technique that uses a checklist of action verbs (Substitute, Combine, etc.) to generate new ideas by transforming existing ones.

A cognitive framework or concept that helps organize and interpret information. Schemas are mental structures of preconceived ideas, allowing us to take shortcuts in interpreting the vast amount of information available in our environment.
The defined boundaries of a project's work.
The act of intentionally reducing the scope of a project to meet constraints.
A written representation of a musical composition or a plan of action.
The ability to monitor and manage one's own cognitive and emotional processes.

The correct method for acting in the Complicated domain of the Cynefin framework. It involves gathering data (Sense), using expert knowledge to understand it (Analyze), and then executing the resulting plan (Respond).

The correct method for acting in the Clear domain of the Cynefin framework. It involves recognizing a known situation (Sense), sorting it into a pre-defined category (Categorize), and applying the established best practice (Respond).
To perceive by a sense or senses.
The action of helping or doing work for someone.
To give a portion of something to others.
A gesture, action, or sound that is used to convey information.
The power to evoke enduring images, memories, and emotions.
A rough or unfinished drawing.
The ability to see the connection between personal problems and larger social issues.
A detailed description of the design and materials used to make something.
A short, one-sentence description of what a team plans to achieve during a Scrum sprint.
The requirements and desires of individuals or groups who have an interest in a project.
The practice of articulating the strongest possible version of an opponent's argument before refuting it.
The responsible overseeing and protection of something considered worth caring for and preserving.
A sequence of visual panels used to plan a time-based experience like a film or user journey.
An Indigenous methodology where stories are enacted to renew relationships.
A plan of action designed to achieve a major aim.
The arrangement of and relations between the parts of something complex.
The original term for Tool 5, representing the act of giving a definite form or organization to an idea.
The devotion of time and attention to acquiring knowledge on a subject.
An evaluation that 'sums up' a student's learning at the end of a unit.
The ability to be maintained at a certain rate or level.
The original term for Tool 9, representing the combination of components to form a connected whole.
A set of connected things or parts forming a complex whole.
A narrative crafted to transmit a specific lesson, moral, or piece of cultural knowledge.
A state of mental or emotional strain.
A short statement that summarizes the main point or claim of an essay.
A playful, exploratory, and non-linear mode of making that is not strictly plan-driven.
A balance achieved between two desirable but incompatible features; a compromise.
The action of passing something from one person or place to another.
The final phase of testing where actual users test software in a real-world scenario.
An informal explanation of a software feature written from the end user's perspective.
A visualization of the user's journey, organizing tasks by sequence and priority.
The original term for Tool 8, representing the action of checking or proving the accuracy of something.
The consistent practice of high moral and professional standards. In Tool 6, it frames application as an opportunity to embody principles of excellence, care, and integrity.
The faculty or power of using one's will.
The process of ascertaining one's position and following a route.
The act of seeing an event take place.
A hierarchical decomposition of the physical components of a system.
The discrepancy between the brain's expectation (prior model) and sensory reality. This is the primary trigger for learning and inquiry.
In complexity theory, a set of states toward which a system tends to evolve.
The temporary downregulation of the prefrontal cortex (executive control) to allow for flow states and divergent thinking.
A futures research method that deconstructs issues into four layers: Litany, System, Worldview, and Myth.
A strategic exercise where the team imagines a future failure and works backward to determine its cause.
The neural circuit (centered in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex) responsible for assigning subjective value and emotional weight to options during decision-making.
A research approach that emphasizes participation and action, seeking to understand the world by trying to change it, collaboratively and following reflection.
Verification asks 'Did we build the product right?' (conformance to spec). Validation asks 'Did we build the right product?' (conformance to user need).
The sense of the internal state of the body. Used as a data point for 'gut feelings' and intuition.
A living document that tracks all identified risks, their potential impact, and the status of mitigation efforts.
A formal gate in the project lifecycle where the decision authority determines the readiness of the program to progress to the next phase.
The governance structure responsible for setting and enforcing technical standards, independent of the program/project management chain.
A measurement system used to assess the maturity level of a particular technology.
A document that defines the inputs, outputs, and relationship requirements between two or more systems or subsystems.
A small-scale experiment designed to test a hypothesis in a Complex domain where the outcome is unpredictable, but the cost of failure is acceptable.
The reactivation of specific neural patterns during rest (Consolidation Period) that strengthens memory and enables abstraction.
The neural network responsible for detecting behaviorally relevant stimuli and switching between the Default Mode Network and the Executive Control Network.

entries.citation: Argyris, C. (1991). Teaching smart people how to learn. Harvard Business Review, 69(3), 99--109.
entries.rationale: Provides the foundational theory for 'Double-Loop Learning,' the process of questioning underlying assumptions, which is a core objective of Tool 9 (Synthesize) and Tool 10 (Manage).

entries.citation: Argyris, C. (1991). Teaching smart people how to learn. Harvard Business Review, 69(3), 99--109.
entries.rationale: This paper is the foundational source for 'double-loop learning'--changing underlying assumptions, not just actions. This is the core cognitive task of Tool 9 and Tool 10, particularly in the 'Retrospective' and 'Playbook' pathways, adding academic credibility to the synthesis process.

entries.citation: Bakhtin, M. M. (1981). The Dialogic Imagination: Four Essays. University of Texas Press.
entries.rationale: Bakhtin's work is the theoretical foundation for understanding texts and ideas as multi-voiced process of action and responses, which is the central principle of the 'Dialogic Path' (Tool 5).

entries.citation: Bakhtin, M. M. (1981). The Dialogic Imagination: Four Essays. University of Texas Press.
entries.rationale: Grounds the framework's emphasis on dialogue and multiple perspectives. It provides the theoretical basis for understanding meaning as a co-creative act between a work and its audience, which is central to Tool 8 (Present).

entries.citation: Barrett, L. F. (2017). *How Emotions Are Made: The Secret Life of the Brain*. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.
entries.rationale: Provides a key modern theory of emotion (the Theory of Constructed Emotion), grounding the `Interoceptive` and `Emotional` modalities in contemporary affective neuroscience.

entries.rationale: Provides a key modern theory of emotion (the Theory of Constructed Emotion), grounding the Interoceptive and Emotional modalities in contemporary affective neuroscience.

entries.citation: Beaty, R. E., Benedek, M., Silvia, P. J., & Schacter, D. L. (2016). Creative cognition and brain network dynamics. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 20(2), 87--95.
entries.rationale: A key paper supporting the neurocognitive model's description of creative ideation (Tool 3), linking divergent thinking to the dynamic interplay between the Default Mode Network (DMN) and Executive Control Network (ECN).

entries.citation: Beaty, R. E., et al. (2016). Creative cognition and brain network dynamics. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 20(2), 87--95.
entries.rationale: Provides key neuroscientific evidence for the interplay between the Default Mode Network (DMN) and Executive Control Network (ECN) during creative thought, supporting the cognitive model for Tool 3 (Generate).

rubrics.title: Rubric Library
rubrics.introduction:
### The Concept of Dynamic Rubrics

A key principle of a systems-aware framework is that its guiding logic (auxiliary variables) should be adaptable. The rubrics below are presented as general guides, but in practice, they should be contextualized. The definition of 'Exemplary' for a rapid, exploratory prototype is different from that for a final, published paper. Before starting a project, teams should review the rubric and adapt the language in the 'Accomplished' and 'Exemplary' columns to match their specific success criteria.

rows: Application (T6)
The prototype is functional enough to test the core hypothesis, even if buggy or incomplete.
The final artifact is complete, well-crafted, polished, and meets all technical specifications.
Attunement (T1)
Question is superficial or un-testable. Connection to context is unclear.
Question is clear but lacks depth. Some connection to context is made.
Question is focused, relevant, and compelling. Connection to context is clear.
Question is insightful, reframes the issue, and demonstrates deep relational understanding.
Orientation (T2)
Little to no background research. Plan is vague or missing.
Some relevant sources are consulted. Plan is present but lacks detail.
Thorough research is conducted. Plan is clear, logical, and actionable.
Synthesizes diverse sources to map the terrain. Plan is strategic and adaptive.
Application (T6)
Process is disorganized. Fails to produce a coherent artifact.
Follows the plan but struggles with execution. Artifact is incomplete.
Effectively executes the plan. Artifact is complete and meets criteria.
Skillfully adapts the plan during execution. Artifact shows craftsmanship and care.
Refinement (T7)
Dismisses or ignores feedback. Revision is minimal or absent.
Accepts feedback but struggles to implement it effectively.
Actively seeks and incorporates feedback, leading to clear improvements.
Uses feedback to ask deeper questions, leading to transformative revisions.

rows: Environment of Open Communication (T3)
Team members are hesitant to share ideas for fear of judgment. Mistakes are hidden.
Some team members share ideas, but criticism is often personal. Failure is tolerated but not embraced.
Team members feel safe to propose novel ideas and admit mistakes. Feedback is focused on the work.
The team actively celebrates intellectual risk-taking and views failures as the most valuable sources of learning.
Non-defensive listening (T7)
Conversations are dominated by a few voices. Team members interrupt and focus on rebutting.
Team members take turns speaking but listen primarily to formulate their own response.
Team members practice active listening, paraphrasing to confirm understanding before responding.
Team members listen to understand the 'need behind the words,' responding with empathy and helping others clarify their own thinking.
Shared Understanding (T5)
Team members have different, unstated assumptions about the project's goals and plan.
The plan is documented, but team members have varying interpretations of its key components.
The team has a shared, explicit understanding of the goals, plan, and success criteria.
The team co-owns the plan and can articulate not just the 'what' but the 'why' behind strategic decisions, enabling autonomous, aligned action.

overlays.title: Contextual Lenses (Overlays)
overlays.content: These lenses are not tools, but rather cross-cutting concerns that can be applied at any point to deepen understanding. They are organized into two complementary sets.

lenses.name: Critical Lenses: Systems Awareness & Harm Mitigation
lenses.description: These lenses help you see the larger system, uncover hidden biases, and act with responsibility.

lenses.name: Power & Bias
lenses.description: Who benefits from this work? Who might be harmed? What are my biases and how do they shape my approach? Whose voices are being centered, and whose are being marginalized?

lenses.name: Systems Dynamics
lenses.description: How does this work interact with larger systems (social, economic, ecological)? What are the potential feedback loops and unintended consequences? Where is the point of highest leverage for change?

lenses.name: Long-Term Stewardship
lenses.description: What are the long-term resource implications of this work? What is our plan for maintenance or responsible decommissioning? Does this work honor intergenerational responsibilities?

lenses.name: Flourishing Lenses: Well-being & Human Potential
lenses.description: These lenses help you design processes that actively cultivate well-being, resilience, and growth for the creators and the community.

lenses.name: Engagement & Flow
lenses.description: Does this process provide a clear balance of challenge and skill? Does it allow for deep immersion and focus? How can we structure the work to leverage our unique character strengths?

lenses.name: Meaning & Purpose
lenses.description: How does this work connect to a purpose larger than ourselves? Does the process feel significant and worthwhile? How does this work contribute to our legacy?

lenses.name: Resilience & Growth
lenses.description: How can we frame challenges as opportunities for growth? How do we learn from setbacks and failures? Does this process build our capacity to handle future adversity (grit)?

lenses.name: Positive Relationships
lenses.description: Does our process build trust and psychological safety? Are we creating opportunities for constructive, respectful dialogue? How can this work strengthen our connection to our stakeholders and each other?

cognitive_distortions.title: Common Cognitive Distortions in Inquiry
cognitive_distortions.introduction: These are common, unhelpful thought patterns that can block progress. Identifying them is the first step to reframing them.

distortions.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
distortions.description: Seeing things in black-and-white categories. If your performance falls short of perfect, you see yourself as a total failure.
distortions.example: If I don't pick the perfect Guiding Question (Tool 1), this whole project is a waste of time.

distortions.name: Catastrophizing
distortions.description: You anticipate disaster. You ask 'what if' in a negative way.
distortions.example: If this presentation (Tool 8) goes badly, my career is over.

distortions.name: Personalization
distortions.description: You see yourself as the cause of some negative external event which in fact you were not primarily responsible for.
distortions.example: When receiving feedback (Tool 7), thinking 'They think I'm incompetent' instead of 'This section of the work is unclear.'

distortions.name: Mind Reading
distortions.description: You arbitrarily conclude that someone is reacting negatively to you, and you don’t bother to check this out.
distortions.example: During a brainstorm (Tool 3), thinking 'Everyone thinks my idea is stupid' without any evidence.

distortions.name: Perfectionism
distortions.description: The belief that a plan or first draft must be perfect before it can be acted upon or shared.
distortions.example: Getting stuck in 'Analysis Paralysis' (Tool 2) because the plan isn't perfect yet.
